cnd1:3.1: "What is the world surrounded by": "The world," the world of hell, the animal
cnd1:3.2: world, the world of evil spirits, the world of man, the world of heaven, the
cnd1:3.3: world of aggregates, the world of realms, the world of living, this world, other
cnd1:3.4: worlds, the Brahma world, the heavenly world; this is called the world. This
cnd1:3.5: world is covered, covered, obscured, closed, hidden.
cnd1:4.1: Venerable Ajita, like this: "Like this," the continuation of sentences; the
cnd1:4.2: connection of sentences; the completion of sentences; the combination of words;
cnd1:4.3: the connection of words; this is the order of sentences, which is "like this."
cnd1:4.4: "Venerable," this is a synonym of love, respect, respect, and obedience. This is
cnd1:4.5: "Venerable." "Ajita," the name, title, security, common name, appellation.
cnd1:5.1: "Because of what is it not shining": For what is it not shining, not
cnd1:5.2: illuminating, not bright, not being known.
cnd1:6.1: "What do you mean by its adhesion": What is the world's adhesion, binding, and
cnd1:6.2: defilement? Because of what is the world contaminated, strongly contaminated,
cnd1:6.3: closely contaminated (polluted), smeared, mixed, attached, fixed, obstructed; do
cnd1:6.4: you say, you explain, you teach, you inform, you build, you uncover, you
cnd1:7.1: "What is this great horror": What is the world's horror, great terror,
cnd1:8.2: The world is surrounded by ignorance,
cnd1:8.3: Because it is stingy and unrestrained.
cnd1:8.4: I say that craving is its adherence,
cnd1:8.5: And suffering is its great horror.
cnd1:8.7: The world is surrounded by ignorance,
cnd1:8.8: Because it is stingy and unrestrained.
cnd1:8.9: I say that craving is its adherence,
cnd1:8.10: And suffering is its great horror.
cnd1:8.12: The world is surrounded by ignorance,
cnd1:8.13: Because it is stingy and unrestrained.
cnd1:8.14: I say that craving is its adherence,
cnd1:8.15: And suffering is its great horror.

cnd1:8.19: I say that craving is its adherence,

cnd1:8.24: I say that craving is its adherence,
cnd1:8.25: And suffering is its great horror.
cnd1:9.1: "The world is enveloped by ignorance": "Ignorance," ignorance of suffering,
cnd1:9.2: ignorance of the path leading to suffering, ignorance of the past, ignorance of
cnd1:9.3: the future, ignorance of the past and the future, ignorance of the specific
cnd1:9.4: conditionality and the conditioned-arising dhammas, all such ignorance,
cnd1:9.5: invisible, unobserved, unconscious, unenlightened, impassable, unconscious,
cnd1:9.6: unexplored, incorrect view, uninspected, incorrectly seen, inferior wisdom,
cnd1:9.7: unrighteous knowledge, obsession, violent currents of ignorance, harness of
cnd1:9.8: ignorance, ignorance of the underlying tendency of worry, entanglement of
cnd1:9.9: ignorance, fence of ignorance, and root of ignorance are called ignorance.
cnd1:10.1: "Worlds": the world of hell, the animal world, the world of evil spirits, the
cnd1:10.2: world of human beings, the world of heaven, the world of aggregates, the world
cnd1:10.3: of realms, the world of being, this world, other worlds, the world of Brahma,
cnd1:10.4: the world of heaven, are called the world. This world is enveloped, covered,
cnd1:10.5: obscured, closed, hidden, covered by this ignorance.
cnd1:11.1: "Ajita": The Blessed One calls the Brāhmaṇa by his name. "The Blessed One" is
cnd1:11.2: synonymous with respect. In addition, the "greed breaker" is the Blessed One;
cnd1:11.3: the "sickness destroyer" is the Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed conceit"
cnd1:11.4: is the Blessed One; "the one who has destroyed the thorns" is the Blessed One;
cnd1:11.5: "the one who has destroyed the pollutants" is Blessed One; "the one who has
cnd1:11.6: ended" is the Blessed One; "the one who has practiced the body, the precepts,
cnd1:11.7: the mind, and the wisdom" is the Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is close to
cnd1:11.8: the woods, wild forests, and border dwellings (sitting place), where speaking is
cnd1:11.9: lessened, it is quiet, away from the human atmosphere, alone, and suitable for
cnd1:11.10: sitting alone" is the Blessed One; or "the Blessed One is the one who divides
cnd1:11.11: clothes, food, shelter, the needs of patients, and medical necessities"; or "the
cnd1:11.12: Blessed One is the one who has the taste of righteousness, the taste of Dhamma,
cnd1:11.13: the taste of liberation, the increased precepts, the mind, and the wisdom"; or
cnd1:11.14: "the Blessed One is the four types of jhāna, the four immeasurables, the four
cnd1:11.15: formlessness, etc., the one who divides is the Blessed One"; or the Blessed One
cnd1:11.16: is the one who has the eighth liberation, the eight victories, the ninth
cnd1:11.17: dwelling place, etc.; or the Blessed One is the practice of ten thoughts, (ten)
cnd1:11.18: abidings, the one who (observes) the in and out of breath; the one who is purely
cnd1:11.19: divided is the Blessed One; or the Blessed One divides the four mindfulness, the
cnd1:11.20: four righteousness, the four divine bases (iddhipāda), the five faculties, the
cnd1:11.21: five powers, the seven enlightenment factors, and the eight branches of the holy
cnd1:11.22: path; or the Blessed One is ten Tathāgata, four fearlessness, four unobstructed
cnd1:11.23: solutions, six supernatural powers and the six enlightenment methods. "Blessed
cnd1:11.24: One," this name is not given by the mother; not given by the father; not given
cnd1:11.25: by brothers; not given by sisters; not given by friends; not given by relatives;
cnd1:11.26: not given by Samaṇas or Brāhmaṇas; not given by heaven; it is ultimate
cnd1:11.27: liberation; the establishment (of the pseudonym) for the acquisition and
cnd1:11.28: testimony of the Buddha, the Blessed One, under the Bodhi tree, and all
cnd1:11.29: knowledge and wisdom, that is, the Blessed One.
cnd1:12.1: "Because of being stingy and unrestrained, is it not shining": Being stingy is
cnd1:12.2: the five types of stinginess: (right) living stinginess, household stinginess,
cnd1:12.3: gaining stinginess, praise stinginess, dhamma stinginess, everything like this
cnd1:12.4: stinginess, stingy state, greed, heart clenched state, this is called stingy. In
cnd1:12.5: addition, the accumulation of stinginess is also stingy; stinginess in the world
cnd1:12.6: is also stingy; being stingy in opinion is also stingy, this is called stingy.
cnd1:12.7: In evil deeds of the body, or in evil deeds of speech, or in evil deeds of
cnd1:12.8: intention, or in the five desires, being restrained is be turned away, the
cnd1:12.9: heart's abandonment does not arise, or the practice of good Dhamma is not
cnd1:12.10: respected. The state of impermanence, the state of non-stop working, the state
cnd1:12.11: of being stuck to the habit, the state of neglecting desire, the state of
cnd1:12.12: neglecting responsibility, not practicing, not practicing much, not
cnd1:12.13: establishing; relaxation; anything like this state of letting go, this is called
cnd1:12.14: being unrestrained. "Because of being stingy and relaxation does it not shine":
cnd1:12.15: The world is not shining, not illuminating, not bright, not being known because
cnd1:13.1: "I say that craving is its adhering": Aspiration is called craving, that is
cnd1:13.2: greed, lust, acquiescence, conformity, joy, desire, obsession, taking,
cnd1:13.4: fertility, tailoring (greed), net, river, bondage, rope, attachment,
cnd1:13.5: accumulation, companionship, desire, intimate interaction, forest, jungle, love,
cnd1:13.6: expectation, relationship, desire for form, desire for sounds, desire for
cnd1:13.7: smells, desire for tastes, desire for touches, desire for acquisition, desire
cnd1:13.8: for wealth, desire for sons, desire for life, the state of desire, hope, prayer,
cnd1:13.9: greedy appearance, possessing greed, inquiring for profit, illegal greed,
cnd1:13.10: improper greed, hope, envy, desire for desire, desire for nothingness, desire
cnd1:13.11: for form, formless thirst, extinguished thirst, form thirst, sound thirst, smell
cnd1:13.12: thirst, taste thirst, touch thirst, dhamma thirst, torrent, harness, binding,
cnd1:13.13: clinging, obstacles, covering, defilements, potential trends of troubles,
cnd1:13.14: entanglement, vines, stinginess, suffering roots, causes of suffering,
cnd1:13.15: occurrence of suffering, magical nets, magical hooks, magical food, the realm of
cnd1:13.16: the devil, the residence of the devil, the state of the devil, the bondage of
cnd1:13.17: the devil, the river of thirst, the net of thirst, the rope of thirst, the sea
cnd1:13.18: of thirst, craving, greed, and the root of unwholesomeness. This is called
cnd1:13.19: desire. To the world, adhesion, binding, and defilement, because of this desire,
cnd1:13.20: the world is contaminated, polluted, closely contaminated, strongly
cnd1:13.21: contaminated, smeared, mixed, adhered, defiled, obstructed; I say, I explain, I
cnd1:13.22: teach, I tell, I build, I uncover, I analyze, I clarify.
cnd1:14.1: "Suffering is its great horror": "Suffering": suffering from birth, suffering
cnd1:14.2: from old age, suffering from illness, suffering from death, suffering from
cnd1:14.3: sorrow, suffering from despair, suffering from hell, the suffering of the animal
cnd1:14.4: world, suffering from evil spirits, suffering from human beings, the root cause
cnd1:14.5: of suffering, the suffering of entering the womb, the suffering of living in the
cnd1:14.6: womb, the suffering of birth, the suffering of the living being dependent, the
cnd1:14.7: suffering of the living being manipulated by others, the suffering of their own
cnd1:14.8: actions, the suffering from the actions of others, bitterness, diseases of the
cnd1:14.9: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, head, external ear, mouth, tooth, cough, asthma,

cnd1:14.14: sputum, diseases caused by wind, diseases caused by (three) collective diseases,

cnd1:14.17: feces, urine, mosquitoes, wind-scorching snakes, suffering from dead mothers,

cnd1:14.19: the dead daughters, the suffering of relatives' loss, the suffering of the loss
cnd1:14.20: of wealth, the suffering of the loss of disease, the suffering of the decline of
cnd1:14.21: precept, the suffering of the decline of seeing. For all dhammas, from the
cnd1:14.22: beginning, it was known; from extinction, to extinction, it was known, the
cnd1:14.23: retribution is based on kamma; kamma is based on kamma, form is based on name;
cnd1:14.24: name is based on form. Those who are followed by birth, accompanied by birth,
cnd1:14.25: followed by old age, conquered by disease, struck by death, sheltered in
cnd1:14.26: suffering, no shelter, no return, and no refuge are called suffering. This
cnd1:14.27: suffering is the world's terror, great terror, oppression, blow, evil, and

cnd1:16.1: "The streams flow everywhere": "The streams," the flow of thirst, the flow of
cnd1:16.2: seeing, the flow of pollution, the flow of evil deeds, and the flow of
cnd1:16.3: ignorance. "Everywhere," in all places. "Flow," currents, streams; from the eyes
cnd1:16.4: to the forms, flow; from the ears to the sounds..., from the nose to the

cnd1:16.8: smell..., from the tongue to the taste..., from the body to the touch..., the
cnd1:16.9: craving from the intention to the dhamma flows.

cnd1:25.1: "These are closed by wisdom": "Wisdom," that is wisdom, knowledge and
cnd1:25.2: understanding... (omitted), no delusion, choice of Dhamma, right view. "These
cnd1:25.3: are closed by wisdom": These flows are closed and cut off by wisdom, they do not
cnd1:25.4: flow, and do not flow out. "All actions are impermanent," when known and seen,

cnd1:27.1: "Wisdom and mind": "Wisdom," that is being wise, understanding, simple
cnd1:27.2: selection, investigation, discernment, recognition, discrimination, close
cnd1:27.3: observation, inspection, learned virtuous wisdom, proficiency, cleverness,
cnd1:27.4: study, reflection, review, contemplation, examination, general comprehensive
cnd1:27.5: wisdom, vipassanā, right knowledge, stabbing rod, wisdom root, wisdom sword,
cnd1:27.6: wisdom palace, wisdom brightness, wisdom light, no deception, choosing Dhamma,
cnd1:27.7: right view. "Mind," common mind, free mind... (omitted) mindfulness.
cnd1:28.1: "And name and form, dear sir": "Name" is the four formless aggregates. "Form" is
cnd1:28.2: the four great elements and any form derived from the four great elements. "Dear
cnd1:28.3: Sir," this is a language of love, honorific, respectful and obedient language.
cnd1:29.1: "When you are asked about this, please tell me": "I ...this," everything I ask;

cnd1:29.3: asked," when being questioned; when being begged; when being requested; when
cnd1:29.4: being made clear. "Please tell," please explain, please teach, please inform,
cnd1:29.5: please establish, please uncover, please analyze, please clarify.

cnd1:35.1: "The destruction of consciousness, here it is destroyed": The destruction of
cnd1:35.2: consciousness through wisdom, except for the seven beings, all names and forms
cnd1:35.3: that can arise in the endless cycle of rebirth are here annihilated, calmed
cnd1:35.4: down, gone to non-existence, and ceased. Through the way of wisdom, to bring
cnd1:35.5: about the annihilation of consciousness, except for the two beings, all the
cnd1:35.6: names and forms that can arise in the five beings are here destroyed, calmed
cnd1:35.7: down, come to non-existence, ceased. Through the non-return of wisdom, to arise
cnd1:35.8: the destruction of consciousness, except for one existence, all the names and
cnd1:35.9: forms that can arise in the physical and non-material realms are here
cnd1:35.10: annihilated, calmed down, walked to non-existence, and ceased. The Arahant
cnd1:35.11: passes through the non-remaining Nibbāna realm to extinguish the final
cnd1:35.12: consciousness at the time of Nibbāna. Wisdom, mindfulness, name, and form are
cnd1:35.13: all destroyed and calmed here, come down, go to non-existence, cease.

cnd1:37.1: "Those know know the Dhamma": Those who perceive the Dhamma are called Arahants,
cnd1:37.2: those who have exhausted their troubles. For what reason is the enlightened
cnd1:37.3: person called an Arahant, a person who has exhausted their troubles? They are
cnd1:37.4: the perceivers of the Dhamma, the knowers of the Dhamma, the measurers of the
cnd1:37.5: Dhamma, the judges of the Dhamma, the clear ones. "All actions are impermanent,"
cnd1:37.6: the perceiver of the Dhamma, the knower of the Dhamma, the weigher of the
cnd1:37.7: Dhamma, the judge of the Dhamma; "all actions are suffering"..., "all action is
cnd1:37.8: no-self"..., "action is based on ignorance"..., "all dhammas are
cnd1:37.9: extinguished".... Or, to them, it is the enlightened person of the aggregate,
cnd1:37.10: the enlightened person of the realm, the enlightened person of the place, the
cnd1:37.11: enlightened person of coming-around, the enlightened person of rebirth, the
cnd1:37.12: perceiver of reincarnation. Or, they are the inhabitants of the ultimate
cnd1:37.13: (boundary), the ultimate in the world, the ultimate in the place, the ultimate
cnd1:37.14: in the place of going around, the ultimate in the rebirth, those who live the
cnd1:37.15: ultimate, those who have the ultimate, those who are the ultimate in rebirth,
cnd1:37.16: those who are the ultimate in the cycle, the Arahant who holds the last body.
cnd1:38.2: They are the ones who gain the body,)
cnd1:38.3: This is their last, final body.
cnd1:38.4: The reincarnation of life and death,
cnd1:39.1: For this reason, the enlightened person is called an Arahant, a person who has
cnd1:39.2: exhausted his troubles. "Those who know the Dhamma, and everyone learning here":
cnd1:39.3: "There is learning," for what reason are they said to be learning? "They learn,"
cnd1:39.4: hence learning. And what do they learn? They learn to increase precepts, they
cnd1:39.5: learn to increase mind, and they also learn to increase wisdom.
cnd1:40.1: What is meant by "to increase precepts?" Here, the bhikkhu is a preceptor who
cnd1:40.2: lives in the protection of self-control of the Pātimokkha. He has sufficient
cnd1:40.3: righteousness and state of affairs. He sees the horror in minor sins and learns
cnd1:40.4: after accepting from a teacher. Small precepts aggregate and large precept
cnd1:40.5: aggregates are the foundation of abstinence, the (self) inhibition of behavior,
cnd1:40.6: the entrance of self-control, the uppermost of good dhamma, etc., this is to
cnd1:41.1: What is meant by "to increase mind?" Here, the bhikkhu starts from the desire to
cnd1:41.2: escape... (omitted) the first jhāna..., the second jhāna..., the third jhāna...,
cnd1:41.3: after entering, he lives in the fourth jhāna (neither suffering or joyous, from
cnd1:41.4: calm and chanting), this is "to learn to increase mind."
cnd1:42.1: What is learning to increase wisdom? Here, the bhikkhu is a wise person,
cnd1:42.2: possessing the knowledge of arising and passing away; the holy, insight, and the
cnd1:42.3: complete extinction of suffering is (the wisdom), he truthfully knows "This is
cnd1:42.4: suffering. ...(omitted)" "this is hard work."... "this is the path that leads to
cnd1:42.5: suffering"... "these are troubles"... "this is the set of troubles"... "this is
cnd1:42.6: annoyance"... "this is the path leading to troubles;" this is the addition of
cnd1:42.7: wisdom. These three learnings, they learn when they face (note); they learn when
cnd1:42.8: they know; they learn when they see (; when they learn with introspection); they
cnd1:42.9: learn when the mind is established (in a decision); they learn when faith
cnd1:42.10: prevails; they learn with vigor and hard work; when mindfulness arises, they
cnd1:42.11: learn; when mind is set (focused) they learn; when wisdom is learned, they
cnd1:42.12: learn; when they are proved to have known, they learn; they learn through
cnd1:42.13: renunciation; they learn when they practice; they practice well, and sustain
cnd1:42.14: when they are testified, then they go on. For this reason they are called
cnd1:42.15: learning. "Everyone" is the multitude. These learned practitioners are the
cnd1:42.16: Sotāpanna, Sakadāgāmī, Anāgāmī, and Arahant. "Here," in this view, in this
cnd1:42.17: liking, in this inclination, in this proposition, in this Dhamma, in this
cnd1:42.18: teaching, in this practice, in the teachings of this Master, in this individual,
cnd1:43.1: "When the wise are asked about their behavior, my dear sir! Please tell me": You
cnd1:43.2: are the wise and enlightened, who knows the Dhamma and learned the behavior,
cnd1:43.3: conduct, practice, travel, residing, and path. "Are asked," being questioned;
cnd1:43.4: begging, being inquired of; make it clear. "Please tell": please explain, please
cnd1:44.1: <em>8 : (The Blessed One:) You should not be greedy in desire,
cnd1:44.2: And your mind should not be muddy,
cnd1:44.3: Being a skillful person of all dhammas,
cnd1:44.5: <em>8 : (The Blessed One:) You should not be greedy in desire,
cnd1:44.6: And your mind should not be muddy,
cnd1:44.7: Being a skillful person of all dhammas,
cnd1:44.9: <em>8 : (The Blessed One:) You should not be greedy in desire,
cnd1:44.10: And your mind should not be muddy,
cnd1:44.11: Being a skillful person of all dhammas,
cnd1:44.13: <em>8 : (The Blessed One:) You should not be greedy in desire,
cnd1:44.14: And your mind should not be muddy,
cnd1:44.15: Being a skillful person of all dhammas,
cnd1:45.1: "Should not be greedy in desire": "Desire," there are two types of desires: the
cnd1:45.2: desire for things and the desire for pollution. What are the desires for things?
cnd1:45.3: Desirable sight, sound, smell, taste, touch; bedding, clothing, maidservants,
cnd1:45.4: goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants, cows, horses, mules, horses,
cnd1:45.5: fields, houses, gold, gold coins, villages and towns, capitals, countries,
cnd1:45.6: territories, treasuries, warehouses; everything that can be tainted by greed is
cnd1:46.1: In addition, there are past desires, future desires, present desires, internal
cnd1:46.2: desires, external desires, internal and external desires, inferior desires,
cnd1:46.3: medium desires, superior desires; desires in the suffering world, human desires,
cnd1:46.4: heavenly desires, existing desire, created desire, uncreated desire, created
cnd1:46.5: desire by others, possessed desire, unpossessed desire, cherished desire,
cnd1:46.6: non-cherished desires; the desires of all the worlds of desire, the desires of
cnd1:46.7: all the worlds of physicality, all the desires of the world of non-material
cnd1:46.8: worlds, dependence on thirst and desire for love, desiring righteousness, greed
cnd1:46.9: for righteousness, the desire to be intoxicated by righteousness and happiness,
cnd1:46.10: is called the desire for things.
cnd1:47.1: What is the desire for defilement? The desire for desire, the desire for greed,
cnd1:47.2: the desire of desire to greed, the desire of intention, the desire for lust, the
cnd1:47.3: desire for intention, the joy of desire, love obsession, the binding harness of
cnd1:47.4: desire, attachment, the desire for cover.
cnd1:48.2: Wanting to be produced by thought (intention),
cnd1:48.3: I will not think of them,
cnd1:49.1: These are called polluting desires. Craving thirst, attachment, it is greed,
cnd1:49.2: lust... (omitted) unwholesome roots. "Should not be greedy in desire": In the
cnd1:49.3: desire to pollute, one should not be greedy, or obstructed in the desire of
cnd1:49.4: things, should be separated from greed, and those who have excluded greed, have
cnd1:49.5: been freed from greed, have renounced greed, have no greed, have eliminated
cnd1:49.6: greed, those who have attained the cessation of greed, have no hunger and
cnd1:49.7: thirst, those who have extinguished, have become cool, and feel joy, should live
cnd1:50.1: "Mind should not be muddy": "Mind": all the heart, mind, heart, white (clean),
cnd1:50.2: meaning, intentions, consciousness, corresponding to that consciousness. With
cnd1:50.3: evil acts of the body, the mind becomes turbid, agitated, moving, impacting,
cnd1:50.4: volatile, fluctuating, rotating, and restless; acting evil with words...
cnd1:50.5: (omitted), acting evil with intention..., with greed..., aversion..., with
cnd1:50.6: ignorance..., with anger..., with resentment..., in hiding evil..., with
cnd1:50.7: domineering..., with jealousy..., with stinginess..., with hypocrisy..., with
cnd1:50.8: cunning..., with stubbornness..., with passion..., with conceit..., with
cnd1:50.9: arrogance..., with relaxation..., with all pollution..., with all evil deeds...,
cnd1:50.10: with all troubles..., with all the heat (of suffering)...; the unwholesome mind,
cnd1:50.11: turbid, agitated, volatile, fluctuating, rotating, and restless. "The mind
cnd1:50.12: should not be muddy": The mind should not be cloudy: not disturbed, not shaken,
cnd1:50.13: not moved, not rotated, calmed down, and all pollution should be abandoned,
cnd1:50.14: should be discarded, should be driven away, should be ended, should be made to
cnd1:50.15: cease to exist; one should be separated from muddiness and pollution, quashed,
cnd1:50.16: abstained, separated, left, liberated; free from bondage, one should live with
cnd1:51.1: "This is a skillful person of all the Dhamma": "All actions are impermanent",
cnd1:51.2: the skillful one in the Dhamma knows; "all actions are suffering"..., "all
cnd1:51.3: actions are without self"..., "ignorance is the cause of all deeds"....
cnd1:52.1: Or (seeing as) impermanent, the skillful person in all dhammas; it is
cnd1:52.2: suffering... (omitted), it is disease..., it is the tumor..., it is the arrow...
cnd1:52.3: the curse..., the other side..., corruption..., disaster..., movable...,
cnd1:52.4: perishable..., unstable..., it is no refuge..., is miserable..., the root of
cnd1:52.5: misfortune..., hypocritical..., empty..., selfless..., it is the dhamma of
cnd1:52.6: impermanence..., the murderer..., increasing..., bait..., is life..., the method
cnd1:52.7: of old age..., the method of sorrow and despair..., of pollution...,
cnd1:52.8: pleasure..., the extinction..., the trouble..., a good man who renounces for the
cnd1:53.1: Or, the person skillful with the aggregates, ...of the would, ...of the place,
cnd1:53.2: ...with dependent origination, of mindfulness, righteousness, the divine bases,
cnd1:53.3: ...of the root, of power, of consciousness, of support, of the Path, of the
cnd1:54.1: Or, all dhammas are called the twelve sense bases: eyes and forms, ears and
cnd1:54.2: sounds, nose and smell, tongue and taste, body and touch, mind and dhamma; and
cnd1:54.3: because of desire and greed in the inner and outer parts of oneself being cut
cnd1:54.4: off, the roots have been cut off, just like a palm tree without roots, becoming
cnd1:54.5: a non-existent, non-living thing for the future.
cnd1:55.1: "Bhikkhus should march (wander) mindfully": "Mindfully" in four ways: when
cnd1:55.2: practicing mindfulness on the body, when practicing mindfulness on perception,
cnd1:55.3: when watching the mind in the heart, when the practice is in line with the
cnd1:56.1: And again in four ways: the state of avoiding non-mind, the state of the Dhamma
cnd1:56.2: that should be done to the mind, the state of the Dhamma that is obstructed by
cnd1:56.3: the mind, the state of the mindfulness factor (phase) not being forgotten.
cnd1:57.1: And again in four ways: the state of possessing mindfulness, the state of
cnd1:57.2: abiding in mindfulness, the state of experiencing mindfulness, and the state of
cnd1:58.1: And again in four ways: with the state of being mindful as the object of
cnd1:58.2: mindfulness, the quiet state as the object, the calm state as the object, the
cnd1:58.3: state of silence; the recollection of the Buddha, the recollection of the
cnd1:58.4: Dhamma, the recollection of the Saṅgha, the precepts, the alms, of the mind;
cnd1:58.5: mindfulness of the in and out breath, of death, of the body, of silence; all
cnd1:58.6: mindfulness, free-mindfulness..., the path without a fork, are called
cnd1:58.7: mindfulness. Having been fully possessed, reaching fully, possessing, arriving,
cnd1:58.8: with this thought, he is called mindful. "Bhikkhu," he who destroyed the state
cnd1:58.9: of the seven dhammas is called Bhikkhu; seeing is destroyed, suspicion is
cnd1:58.10: destroyed, prohibition..., greed..., anger..., delusion..., sloth...; those evil
cnd1:58.11: and unwholesome dhammas are destroyed: shunning pollution (defilement), the
cnd1:58.12: others, the fear, the bitter fruit, will no longer live for the future.
cnd1:59.5: The one who has been completed,
cnd1:59.6: The one who is extinct, he is a Bhikkhu."
cnd1:60.1: "Bhikkhus should march mindfully": Bhikkhus should proceed mindfully, walk
cnd1:60.2: mindfully, stand mindfully, sit down mindfully, lie down mindfully, go forward
cnd1:60.3: mindfully, step back..., look forward..., observe..., bend..., straighten...,
cnd1:60.4: hold coats, bowls, and clothes mindfully, walk and live mindfully, act, go on,
cnd1:61.1: At the end of the verse, for those who live with the same intention, same
cnd1:61.2: endeavor, same inclination, and same dwelling place as the Brāhmaṇas, the
cnd1:61.3: distant dust and dhamma eyes of thousands of living things arise: "Any
cnd1:61.4: collection of dhammas is an extinction." The mind of the Brāhmaṇa is free from
cnd1:61.5: all defilements without clinging. Along with reaching the realm of the Arahant,
cnd1:61.6: their sheepskin clothing, knotted hair, bark clothing, sticks, long-mouthed
cnd1:61.7: water bottles, hair, and beards disappeared, becoming bald, replaced with robes,
cnd1:61.8: cloth clothes, overcoats, and bowls. They clasp their hands together to show
cnd1:61.9: respect to the Blessed One, and sit down: "Great Virtue! The Blessed One is my
cnd1:61.10: teacher, and I am a disciple."
